start.dataManagementPlans:
Data management plans
Plan ahead
Data management plans (DMPs) are increasingly required by funding agencies – either as part of the research proposal, or as an early project deliverable. Costs for data management (software, hardware, technical expertise) can often be included in research proposals. Even without a formal obligation, you may do yourself a favor creating a “private” data management plan.
 
Data management plans shouldn’t be viewed as bureaucratic hurdles or “compliance tick boxes”, but as an integral part of research practice. They are (or should be) living documents that might require revisions or updates as research progresses and data are acquired and processed: Details become clear, initial plans may change, unforeseen collaboration opportunities could arise, …. .
 
Data management plans generally cover the following aspects:
  • Data description and collection
    • Which data will be generated (types, formats, volume)? Types could include e.g. numeric, textual, image, audio, video, … . Formats are often indicated by the filename extension. Proprietary formats (created by scientific instruments and/or specific software applications) should be converted to open and standard formats at some stage. Volume can be described in terms of number of files as well as total file size.
    • Will the project re-use existing data? If not, has this possibility been explored?
  • Documentation and metadata
    • What is needed for others (as much as possible, also beyond your own scientific field) to find, understand and potentially reuse your data? Documentation might include definition of variables, details of methodology, approaches to quality control, … .
    • Metadata should be comprehensive and follow community standards whenever available.
    • File organization and nomenclature might be described in this section.
  • Storage and backup
    • Where will data be stored during the project? Is sufficient storage available? How, and how frequently will data be backed up? Multiple backups at different locations are strongly recommended.
    • How are data generated in the field transferred to more secure locations?
    • How will data be recovered in case of incidents?
    • How will data be protected to prevent unauthorized access, particularly for sensitive data (e.g. containing personal information)?
  • Legal and ethical requirements
    • In case of personal data, how is compliance with applicable regulations and laws (e.g. GDPR) assured?
    • Are there other restrictions on sharing data, such as intellectual property rights or plans to seek for patents?
  • Data sharing and long-term preservation
    • Which data will be made freely available, and when? How will potential reusers find out that, and where/how datasets are available? Will data be deposited in a repository, or shared by other means?
    • Will data be assigned with persistent identifiers? Will licenses clarify conditions of reuse?
    • Will access to data be limited, e.g. restricted to certain communities or subject to data sharing agreements?
    • Also for data that aren’t shared: How is long-term preservation (beyond the lifetime of the project) assured, and for how long?
  • Responsibilities and resources
    • Who will be responsible for data management, implementing the DMP and updating it as needed? This could be one or several named person(s) or an institution. Different parts of the data management process may be spread over several roles.
    • How are responsibilities defined and/or split in collaborative research projects?
    • Which resources (e.g. software, hardware, technical expertise) are required for data management? Which costs are involved, and how will these be covered?
This information is often preceded by administrative data (e.g. funder, project, grant reference number, principal investigator, version of DMP). The level of detail appropriate or required in DMPs will differ between projects and scientific fields, particularly regarding data documentation.
 
Tools for creation of data management plans
"You don't have to re-invent the wheel!"
 

Two online tools are available (registration required):

 
DMPonline by the British Digital Curation Centre (DCC). The webpage includes templates by mostly (but not only) British funding agencies, as well as a wide range of public DMPs.
 
DMPTool by the University of California Curation Center also has templates and sample plans, mostly for US funding agencies. The related blog includes a discussion of efforts to make DMPs machine-actionable.
 
RDMO (Research Data Management Organizer) by Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam, University of Applied Sciences Potsdam and Karlsruhe Institute of Technology requires software installation on a local server. It is productive or in a test phase at a range of German universities and research institutes. Development is ongoing, it goes beyond data management into project management.
 
GFBio (German Federation for Biological Data) also has a Data Management Plan Tool. You can obtain feedback/support from their experts on the draft version of a DMP.
 
Further DMP examples
Digital Curation Centre Example DMPs and Guidance
 
LIBER Europe DMP Catalogue
 
Further reading
Science Europe Practical Guide to the International Alignment of Research Data Management (includes core requirements for data management plans and guidance)
 
DLCM Data Management Checklist [detailed guidance by Swissuniversities DLCM – Data Life Cycle Management]
 
Michener WK (2015) Ten Simple Rules for Creating a Good Data Management Plan. PLoS Comput Biol 11(10): e1004525. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004525 
[general article, not specific for the field of computational biology]
start.fileFormats:
Sustainable (open) file formats
Make sure your data remain readable 
If a file and its desired version can be located, you (or others) might still be unable to open it and read its content. 
This is more likely to happen on longer (archival) timescales, and for data sharing beyond a project team (with people lacking access to specific dedicated tools). Some decisions and actions could be postponed until later in the research process.
Proprietary vs. open formats
 
Proprietary formats often aren’t readable without the corresponding (commercial) software, and may become obsolete in the future. WordPerfect (.wpd) is just one example of a format that used to be common and popular, but is currently at most ‘exotic’. Readability of data generated by scientific instruments may depend on the underlying and not widely available software.
 
Conversion from proprietary to open formats may result in some loss of data and/or context (formatting, embedded metadata, …). In such cases, it may be advisable to save data in both proprietary and open formats – if you can no longer read the proprietary format, you then lose something but not everything … .
 
Open formats are preferred, but another reason for using (and keeping) a proprietary format could be that it is (far) more commonly used. Two aspects might require consideration when choosing file formats:
  • Is there loss of information? Uncompressed formats are preferable, but storage requirements could become prohibitive – particularly for large sets of files. Lossy compression results in permanent loss of information, effects may be limited and go unnoticed by users – a certain degree of lossy compression may be deemed acceptable. Effects can be exacerbated if a file is saved several times in a format with lossy compression (“digital generation loss”). Lossless compression is less efficient in reducing file sizes, but a file can be restored to its original state. Yet, all compressed file formats are more vulnerable to bit rot: changes in one or a few bits may cause major changes across the entire document and render it useless.
  • Is there a need to edit/manipulate saved files? For example, the .pdf format is not suitable for tabulated numerical data if access to numbers is needed for e.g. visualization, sorting, filtering, statistical analyses, …. .
File format sustainability factors
The Library of Congress defines seven “sustainability factors for digital formats” (other sources use similar criteria):
Disclosure, Adoption, Transparency, Self-documentation, (limited) external dependencies, Impact of patents, Technical protection mechanisms. Read more
 
Comprehensive coverage by Library of Congress includes discussion of various content categories (still image, sound, textual, moving image, …). The list of recommended formats is updated annually.
Recommended file formats

For some data types, there is no broad consensus on preferred formats, the following list is for indicative guidance:

 
Type of data Recommended formats Comments
Text Plain text (.txt)
Rich Text format (.rtf)
Open Document Text (.odt)
PDF (PDF/A-1)		 Encoding for all formats preferably UTF-8
Alternative: .docx (ISO standard) is acceptable but avoid proprietary formats (such as .doc)
PDF/A (pdf format for archival purposes) if layout is relevant
[see also: Notes on pdf format]

 
Tabular (minimal metadata) Comma-separated values (.csv)
Tab-delimited (.tab)		 Alternative: .xlsx (ISO standard) widely used and thus acceptable
Tabular (extensive metadata) SPSS portable format (.por)
NetCDF		 Alternative: proprietary formats of statistical packages acceptable
Images TIFF6.0 uncompressed (.tif)
JPEG2000 (.jp2)
JPEG (.jpg)
GIF (.gif)
Scalable Vector Image (.svg)		 TIFF is proprietary but widely used and well-documented
JPEG2000 provides lossless compression but isn’t widely adopted (“niche format”)
JPEG has lossy compression
.svg for vector images
Geospatial ESRI Shapefile
Geography Markup Language (.gml)
Geo-referenced TIFF		  
Video MPEG-4 (.mp4)
OGG video (.ogv, .ogg)		  
Audio Free Lossless Audio Codec (.flac)
Waveform Audio File Format (.wav)		 Alternative: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 (.mp3) has lossy compression, acceptable if original generated in this format
start.fileHandling:
File nomenclature, organization and versioning
Be organized!
How do you keep track of all files generated during a scientific project? How do you deal with changes that can occur during data processing and analysis, or while editing a text document (e.g. report)? 
Several people may be involved, it is highly recommended to define practices prior to the start of a project, and observe such practices throughout the research process.
 
When you (or others from your team) look for a specific file, maybe long after it has been generated, in what terms do you think? 
It could be, among other things, time period, creator, activity or data collection method (e.g. experiment), geographic location, or document type (e.g. presentation or report). File names should be descriptive, providing useful cues to content of a file independent of its location on a computer – files may be transferred, and the folder structure context could be lost.
 
File nomenclature
What is (or could/should be) in a [file] name?
 
Some suggested Dos and Don’ts for file nomenclature:
Do (Good practice)
  • include relevant information in file names. This may include project, investigator (initials), experiment, location, date, parameter, status of data (raw, processed, …), file version (see below), or anything else deemed relevant in a given context.
  • use YYYYMMDD for dates (e.g. 20160802) and put date at the beginning or end of file names, both to facilitate chronological sorting. YYMMDD may suffice, but isn’t as self-explanatory/may be ambiguous (160802 could also be 4:08:02PM).
  • use leading zeros for other numbers as needed (001, 002, …. 011, …. 114 rather than 1, 2, ….. 11, ….. 114), also to allow files to be properly sorted.
  • use dashes (file-name.xxx) or underscores (file_name.xxx) to separate parts of a filename.
  • generate a Readme file explaining file nomenclature (including the meaning of acronyms or abbreviations), file organization and versioning. Store this file on top of a folder structure for easy access.
  • be consistent throughout a project, also when several people are involved.
Don’t (Questionable practice)
  • use special characters such as ~ ! / \ @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) ` ; < > ? , [ ] { } ‘ “| as they may have specific meanings in certain operating environments. Also avoid ä ö ü ß å ø ñ or similar.
  • use dots . other than before the file extension
  • use spaces in file names – they might end up being truncated during file transfer (with the file extension also lost and files potentially becoming unreadable).
  • make file names overly long (a maximum of 32 or 24 characters is suggested) – this may involve compromises regarding the first Do criterion
 

Good example:

20140618_exp08_co2data_proc_v01.csv

( proc represents “processed” )

 

Bad example:

CO2data (exp8) June 18 2014.csv

This contains (nearly) the same information, but: when numerous files are sorted, the order will be e.g. exp11 ahead of exp8, August-July-June-March, June 18 2014 ahead of June 27 2013. Sorting by “date modified” (external to the file name) won’t help either if you made even minor changes to some of the files at variable later moments. Spaces and special characters () in the filename might cause problems in certain situations. Are these raw or processed data??

 
Very bad example:

DSC_258.jpg

This is how an image is saved by a digital camera, but it doesn’t reveal anything about the image. File properties may contain some relevant information such as date created and maybe location, but do you want to check this manually for hundreds of images? Changing the filename immediately (or as soon as possible) will save you trouble later on, e.g. Fieldwork_PA_160819_1624.jpg . Make sure that you (and others) will always understand that PA means Pennsylvania, and that 1624 is time (hour and minute, local or GMT – either may be fine but be consistent) rather than 1624th image on the given day.

 
See also: Stanford Libraries Best Practices for File Naming
 
Information above is based on this and other sources. The Stanford pages include a poor and a well-done case study – the latter requires detailed documentation to be understandable also for people external to the project (and dots in the file names weren’t considered problematic).
 
File organization/folder structure
This may also require judgement and compromises: a very deep folder structure (subsubsubsubsubfolders) can be as inconvenient as a folder with 100 or more individual files.
 
Whatever your choice is in the end, it makes sense to define your strategy early in the research process. Re-organizing everything halfway during a project, towards its end or close to a deadline can be tedious and time-consuming. Yet working with a sub-optimal file structure for lack of time to implement major changes, or out of inertia, can also be annoying.
 
For a Ph.D. thesis, the folder structure could include e.g. Literature (by others), Publications (own ones), Thesis (Ph.-D. relevant material), Projects (here side projects), Pictures, Experiments (setup and documentation), Data (keep raw data separate from processed data). Experiments and data could be sorted thematically, chronologically, geographically (several fieldwork locations) or in another way, and the folder structure might be flat or deep – whatever seems to work best in the given case.
 
File versioning
Track changes over time (and research progress)
 
Documents may evolve over time, several people may be involved in sequential changes. For data (of any kind, e.g. numeric or images) and text documents alike, file versioning serves two purposes:
  • You can revert to earlier versions if needed.
  • You can keep track of changes, including documentation on the underlying rationale and people involved.
Versions should be numbered consecutively, distinguishing major changes (v1, v2, v3, …) from minor ones (v1-1, v1-2, v1-3 or 1a, 1b, 1c). Use leading zeros if you expect more than nine versions. However: Do NOT apply such numbering when using version control software, as it will interfere with automatic versioning.
 
Qualifiers such as “raw” or “processed” for data, or “draft” or “internal” for documents are fine. So is “final” BUT don’t use confusing terms such as final2, final-revised, final-changed_again, final_really, ….. . In other words: Assign “final” only when you are sure that no further changes will occur. This might be the case after a document has been approved by everyone involved, or was accepted for publication.
 
As applicable, versioning should include documentation on
  • What has changed, and why?
  • How were changes implemented (e.g. data processing steps)?
  • Who was involved and/or responsible?
Such information may be included within documents, and/or provided separately.
 
In case of many revisions, in order to keep an overview of major/relevant changes it may be appropriate to discard some of the minor versions, or to store them in a separate (“Archive”) location. Less relevant versions could e.g. include abandoned data processing steps (flawed or inefficient approaches).
start.legalAndEthical:
Legal and ethical aspects
Respect privacy of study participants
Some data cannot be (freely) shared, or only if special measures are taken. These measures require consideration and action throughout the research process, some are prerequisites for research to be carried out in the first place. This section focuses on personal data and privacy issues, other cases are data revealing precise locations of endangered species or vulnerable archaeological sites and data with potential for dual use – civil and military with possible abuse by terrorists.
 
Human participants are often willing, sometimes even eager to participate in and thus contribute to scientific research. But they may care about their privacy. Trust between researchers and study participants has to be created and needs to be maintained. Study participants may not want their personal data to be (re-)used by others whom they do not trust, and/or for purposes which they do not approve.
 
We provide general guidance followed by links to applicable regulations and other resources with more detailed coverage of some topics. Max Planck Digital Library does not provide legal advice. Professional legal advice should be sought if you are unsure about legal requirements placed on your (planned) research.
 
What are personal data?
All data that allow to identify a person, directly or indirectly. Three categories can be distinguished:
  • direct identifiers can be unambiguously linked to a single person, e.g. name, address, phone number, social security number (and similar), email address (if revealing name and possibly employer) but also unique profession (e.g. CEO of a named company), pictures, voices, … .
  • indirect identifiers can reveal the identity of a person taken together in the same dataset, and possibly combined with information from other sources. Indirect identifiers include birth date/age, place of residence/zip code, rare profession, income, ….. .
    The potential for identification is currently much higher than decades ago, because a lot of information is readily and often freely available on the Internet. For studies covering a mentioned small area, local knowledge and personal information about other people (what do I know about my neighbors?) also has to be taken into account.
  • special personal data (also referred to as “sensitive data”): racial/ethnic origin, political opinion, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, sexual activity and/or orientation, health data, genetic and biometric data.

Direct identifiers should be removed as soon as possible during the research process, special personal data should only be collected if relevant for the given study. Generally, data minimisation implies that data that aren’t needed to answer a study question shouldn’t be collected in the first place.

 
Ethics approval 
Some research will require prior approval by a Research Ethics Committee or Institutional Review Board. Many German universities have an ethics committee at the medical faculty/university hospital – see Arbeitskreis medizinischer Ethik-Kommissionen in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland e.V. – which can also assess research projects by Max Planck researchers falling into their field of expertise. If this option isn’t available, the MPG project leader can contact the Ethics Council of the Max Planck Society for an ethics vote.
 

See also: Ethikkommission Deutsche Gesellschaft für Psychologie and psychological faculties of universities, Ethikkommission Deutsche Gesellschaft für Sprachwissenschaft, Ethikkommission Deutsche Gesellschaft für Erziehungswissenschaft

 
Informed consent by study participants and data anonymisation are two key aspects for generating, processing and (possibly) sharing data from research on human subjects. Anonymisation has to be balanced with data utility. If sufficient data anonymisation compromises data utility, data may still be shared under restricted access (see below).
 
Informed consent
Study participant: "What's going on?"
 
 
Before giving consent, participants of scientific studies have to know which personal data will be collected, archived and potentially shared, and which steps will be taken to safeguard anonymity and confidentiality. If special (sensitive) data are collected, this has to be clearly mentioned. Information sheets on the project should include its purpose and benefits as well as possible risks for participants.
 
All documents should be written in language understandable to participants, and be concise while complete. Participants must have the opportunity to ask questions, and must be provided with contact details for questions that may arise at a later stage.
 
If these requirements are met, a participant can make a voluntary informed choice to accept or refuse to cooperate. Consent will often be specific, i.e. linked to the stated purpose of a scientific study, “broad consent” (allowing personal data to be used for any scientific purpose) is considered controversial.
 
It must be possible to withdraw consent at any later stage, as easily as giving consent and without providing reasons. Participants must be clearly informed about (lack of) consequences of refusal to participate, or later withdrawal of consent.
 
Delicate situations can arise if the participant is in a dependency relation to the researcher (e.g. patient – medical doctor or student – supervisor), or in a situation of restricted freedom. In such cases, consent should be obtained by another person lacking such a relationship with the (prospective) study participant.
 

Written or oral consent? 

Written consent is preferable, as it facilitates documentation and allows clarification of the extent of consent. However, written consent may not be possible in some cases, e.g. informal research settings or participants wary of formal documentation (e.g. refugees). Oral consent may be acceptable, while it can be difficult to make all issues clear verbally. Such consent should ideally be recorded (video or audio) or be obtained in the presence of a witness.
 
So far, it has been assumed that study participants are capable of and legally entitled to giving consent. If this is not the case, consent has to be obtained from parents/guardians (for children) or legal representatives (in case of mental illness or dementia). To the extent possible, participants should still be asked, with assent registered and dissent respected. It also has to be justified why a study needs to include participants unable to provide consent.
 
Research without consent may be necessary if participants cannot be informed in advance, because knowledge of the underlying research question would invalidate the method. Such research is possible, but will be subject to rigorous ethical review, ensuring that three criteria are met:
  1. clear value and benefit of research
  2. no alternative research design possible to address the research question
  3. no or very minimal risk of harm to participant
Data anonymisation
Anonymisation aims that data can no longer be linked (unambiguously or tentatively) to an individual person, sufficiently anonymised data are no longer considered personal data. Anonymisation is irreversible and thereby distinct from reversible pseudonymisation, where data and personal identifiers are stored separately and can again be combined with each other.
 
Anonymisation techniques may include
  • removal of direct identifiers, as well as indirect identifiers that can’t be treated with other techniques
  • generalization of data, providing ranges rather than precise values or not revealing details: e.g. age 20-30, 30-40, 40-50, … , only first three digits of zip codes, region rather than village
  • top-encoding rare values or outliers: e.g. age 80 or higher, monthly net income 7500 Euros or higher, three or more children, “other” for rare mother tongue in a given context
  • distorting data by adding small numbers to parameters, or some noise – precluding identification of individuals while not affecting statistical analysis and interpretation of data
 
Qualitative data (e.g. interviews and their transcripts) pose additional challenges: Personal identifiers may occur throughout a document rather than in a structured and predictable way, study participants may reveal information about third parties. Such documents need to be carefully edited, names might be replaced by roles [husband, friend, teacher] or by he/she. Modifications should be clearly marked, for example a “random” name chosen to replace a real one might be the real name of another person.
 
Search/replace functions of software can be helpful but should be used with care and manually checked: some replacements might be unnecessary, while other personal identifiers are overlooked (e.g. due to typos). Editing video or audio documents can be technically challenging, it may be better to share only transcripts.
 
If individual data points are retained, anonymisation will never be guaranteed – there will always be a residual risk of re-identification. Risk assessment should include this risk, as well as the potential for inconvenience or harm to study participants if data are exposed.

Source: modified from understandingpatientdata.org.uk License CC BY

 
Only aggregated data (summary statistics of large datasets not revealing individual data points) offer guaranteed anonymity. But usability of aggregated data may be limited, both in terms of verifying some research conclusions and to address new research questions.
 
If sufficient data anonymisation compromises data utility, or if the residual risk of identification and/or related consequences for participants is considered to be substantial, data containing personal information may still be shared under restricted access, with only metadata and study description freely available. Data use agreements then generally specify that users will
  • use such data only for a defined scientific purpose (relevant and consistent with informed consent from study participants)
  • refrain from attempts at re-identification of study participants
  • refrain from sharing data with third parties
 
Legal framework and guidelines for biomedical research
 
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
 
Bundesdatenschutzgesetz (new version 2018, German implementation of EU regulations)
 
WMA Declaration of Helsinki – Ethical Principles for Medical Research Involving Human Subjects
 
Guideline for Good Clinical Practice
 
International ethical guidelines for health-related research involving humans CIOMS (Council for International Organizations of Medical Science)
 
Oviedo Convention: protecting human rights in the biomedical field
 
Belmont Report: Ethical Principles and Guidelines for the Protection of Human Subjects of Research (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services)
 
See also: Dankar, FK, Gergely, M, Dankar, SK (2019): Informed Consent in Biomedical Research. Computational and Structural Biotechnology Journal 17, 463-474.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csbj.2019.03.010 
[Mini Review on historical developments and current practice for Big Data]
 
Further reading
CESSDA (Consortium of European Social Science Data Archives) 
Data Management Expert Guide – legal and ethical considerations in creating shareable data
 
UK Data Service – Legal and ethical issues
 
European Commission Ethics and data protection
 
In German: Kreutzer, Till; Lahmann, Hennig (2019) Rechtsfragen bei Open Science. Ein Leitfaden. Hamburg University Press [Teil 1.IV Persönlichkeitsrechte und Datenschutz]
start.overview:
Before research
Think ahead !
Thinking about data management requirements before new data are even generated may be considered premature. But time spent at this stage can save lots of time later in the research process: it’s easier to think about data organization and documentation beforehand than to reconstruct details that you may no longer readily remember, let alone not at all.
 
This section covers aspects that should be considered from the very start, while some of them matter throughout the research process.

 


Data management plans

Legal and Ethical



How to deal with personal research data
 

 


File handling

File organization/folder structure
File versioning
 

 


File formats

start.pdfFormat:
Notes on pdf format
The pdf format conserves layout rather than structured content. It is widely adopted and well-suited for dissemination, but has limitations for archival and digital preservation. This primarily refers to automated metadata extraction (even basic bibliographic elements) with machine-based technology. As already mentioned, pdf also isn’t suitable for tabulated numeric data because these data cannot be (readily) re-used.
 
The purpose of this essay is to describe the pdf format and its limitations, and to offer (partial) solutions for archival purposes.
 
General description of pdf format
PDF has become a de facto format for exchange of print-oriented documents, ensuring robust visual presentation across a variety of operating systems and platforms and preserving the author’s intent in finalized form. It was partly designed for the Internet and is thus well-suited for documents available on-line.
 
While proprietary in origin, it is now part of a family of ISO standards. In 2008, control of specifications was passed to an ISO committee of voluntary industry experts (including, but not limited to Adobe Inc.). Adobe Reader is freely available (no definite guarantee that this will always be the case), third parties can develop PDF tools.
 
PDF files most commonly contain text, graphic paths and/or images and may also incorporate e.g. video/audio and hyperlinks to external content. They become incompatible with source files: The initial image format is not conserved, and it is difficult to convert pdf files back into Microsoft Word – paragraphs, formatting, line breaks etc. are not preserved.
 
PDF/A for archival purposes and Tagged PDF
The PDF/A format is designed to be self-contained without external dependencies: Fonts have to be embedded (rather than linked), device-independent color information has to be provided. Forbidden content includes audio, video, JavaScript and executable file launches. However, annotations such as hyperlinks are allowed – while not necessarily permanent. PDF/A preserves additional information in documents beyond what is needed for printing.
 
Tagged PDF provides markup for real content (structure of documents) while ignoring artifacts such as page numbers. The aim is to embed logical structure for accessibility and repurposing of content.
 
Challenges in automated metadata extraction
As the PDF format conserves layout and design rather than logical document structure, automated extraction of even basic bibliographic metadata (title, publisher, authors, affiliations, …) is challenging. Humans can recognize the format of text from layout and overcome inconsistencies and vagueness from different layouts used by different publishers, but machine-based technology cannot. Machines cannot infer structure from design choices.
 
Numerous automated tools exist (details beyond the scope of this essay), using different approaches aiming for bulk processing without user interaction, high accuracy and high adaptivity (to diverse formatting layouts). But all tools are error-prone – note that 80% success means 20% failure! Ideally, metadata are stored within a PDF file – but this is rarely the case (and if so, not in a standardized way), hence full text has to be analyzed.
 
Additional challenges are due to
  • scanned documents (rather than born digital), requiring OCR (optical character recognition) for processing of text content
  • badly formed pdf’s (created by a multitude of software tools). Adobe Reader has a high tolerance for rendering invalid pdf files. Digital collections are very likely to contain badly formed pdf files, but consequences for long-term preservation and future access are unclear.
  • the multitude of different pdf versions over the years
 
Recommendations
  • Provide PDF files in PDF/A format and as tagged PDF. Both has to be intentionally selected (Save as PDF -> Options). Note that an existing generic PDF file cannot be sensibly converted to PDF/A because relevant information has been lost during conversion of a source file to PDF.
  • Provide metadata within a PDF file. Ideally or rather hypothetically, this should be done in a standardized way – however, currently standards do not exist.
  • If possible, provide the original format(s) and/or a machine-readable format (e.g. XML) along with a PDF file.
 
“PDF/A is not a preservation solution on its own: rather it needs to integrate with other components of a wider preservation strategy” [Digital Preservation Coalition UK]
start.sustainabilityFactors:
Sustainability factors for digital file formats (Library of Congress)
  • Disclosure – Do complete specifications and tools for validating technical integrity exist, and are freely available (rather than company secrets)? Digital preservation requires an understanding of how the information is represented (encoded) as bits and bytes in digital files.
  • Adoption by primary creators, disseminators and users of information resources. A widely used format is less likely to become (rapidly) obsolete. If it still becomes outdated at some stage, tools for migration of file formats or emulation of their soft- and hardware environment are more likely to emerge. It may however be hard to predict whether a format remains popular over many years.
  • Transparency – Are file formats open to direct analysis with basic tools? If the underlying information is represented simply and directly, it can be more easily migrated if need should arise.
  • Self-documentation – Are metadata included within the file? Basic descriptive metadata are analogous to the title page of a book.
  • (Limited) external dependencies – degree to which a format depends on specific hardware, software or operating systems and predicted complexity of dealing with such requirements in future technical environments.
  • Impact of patents – This depends on terms chosen by patent holders, widespread adoption of a format may indicate that patents do not pose problems for long-term archiving.
  • Technical protection mechanisms such as encryption pose problems for long-term archival and dissemination, migration to new formats, transfer to new storage media, … .

running.overview:
During research
Safety first!
The main data management task during the research process is to store data safely as they are generated, with regular backups. At this stage, data are generally shared only within a research team. A team may include external partners (other groups/departments from the same institute, other Max Planck institutes and beyond the Max Planck Society).
 
Numerous MPDL tools/services are available to Max Planck researchers and – upon invitation – their external collaborators. Additional (more discipline-specific) ones may exist at individual institutes.
Tooools!
 
 
Storing data solely on a local harddisk, laptop or USB stick is very risky and therefore not recommended. Storage media may deteriorate or could be lost, stolen, damaged or destroyed (e.g. during a fire). You might also delete data accidentally. A good rule of thumb is to store data three times, on two different media, with one copy off-site (3-2-1 rule). Backups should be performed regularly – automatic backups are better than manual ones which you might forget. Also verify that backups are working, and that you have access to these files.
 
See also: Perker, J.M., 2019: 11 ways to avert a data-storage disaster. Nature 568, 
doi: 10.1038/d41586-019-01040-w.
 
Topics covered in the previous section may require ongoing attention: A data management plan needs to be followed, and may have to be updated while research is ongoing. Sensitive personal data obviously require special care throughout the research process.

MPDL Services for researchers
We are here to help you! 
MPDL services help researchers during data acquisition, safe data storage and collaborative working on data as they are generated. Services for finalized datasets (long-term archival and, if applicable, open sharing of research data) will be mentioned in the "After research" chapter.
 
All services are available to Max Planck researchers and - upon invitation - their external collaboration partners. Your data will stay within the Max Planck Society.

labfolder

LabCam

Tools for data storage and collaborative working

Keeper

«collective»

 
 
Electronic laboratory notebook advice
Thorough documentation of experimental procedures (sample preparation, instrument settings, calibration, quality control, …) for data acquisition is essential to answer questions that can arise during later phases of the research process: data processing and synthesis, interpretation and writing up of results in scientific papers or Ph.D. thesis.
 
Traditionally-historically, such laboratory notes were taken on paper, which has several disadvantages:
  • It is not possible to include information already present in digital form, namely most output of scientific instruments (all that can be done, and is done is paste/glue printouts).
  • Your handwriting may be(come) illegible for others, or even for your future self.
  • Paper notes cannot be accessed remotely.
  • Major projects may require a series of labbooks.
  • Paper notes aren’t automatically searchable, thus retrieving details well after an experiment was conducted may be tedious and time-consuming – if at all possible.
  • Paper notes cannot be easily edited – no options such as Copy, Paste, Delete or Insert (text).
  • It isn’t possible to create and use templates for recurrent processes.
  • Paper notes have limited if any options for contributions by multiple group members.
 

 
Electronic laboratory notebooks (ELNs) offer far more flexibility, structure to data and digital preservation potential. Various ELN solutions have different features that may be particularly suitable for certain scientific fields or analytical methods – MPDL can make suggestions after discussing your specific needs.
 
labfolder is the ELN solution licensed for all Max Planck researchers and their project partners.

Edmond institutional research data repository
 
Edmond, the institutional Open Research Data Repository of the Max Planck Society, provides Max Planck researchers and (upon invitation) their external collaborators with a home to publish/share their data from all scientific disciplines.

finalize.licences:
Data licences
Clarify conditions of data (re-)use
Published research data have limited (or no) potential for reuse if users do not know what they can do with the data, subject to which conditions. It is therefore crucial to assign a licence to a dataset. Community standards and good scientific practice should still be observed even if not enforced by licences.
Creative Commons
Creative Commons licences were initially designed for cultural material, but in the latest version 4 are also suitable for scientific data. While not specifically addressing characteristics of (scientific) data, they are widely known and adopted, hence users will be familiar with their meaning. All licences come with a short summary (in many languages) understandable without legal background, as well as the full licence text.
 
Recommended licences are CC BY (Attribution) or CC0 (Public Domain, No Rights Reserved). CC BY obliges re-users to give credit to data producers (without implying endorsement). CC0 doesn’t include such a formal obligation, but good scientific practice still requires giving due credit.
 
Other conditions can be imposed but aren’t recommended for various reasons: SA (ShareAlike) imposes that works derived from data are distributed under the same licence (“copyleft”) – this can pose problems if data from various sources provided with different licences are aggregated. NC (NonCommercial) prohibits commercial use, but it can be difficult to define what exactly represents commercial (re-)use. 
 
Open Data Commons
Open Data Commons licences were designed specifically for data, one key feature is that different licences can be applied to a database as a whole and to its content – this is relevant for example if an image database compiles images from various sources with some images copyrighted. These licences also have human-readable summaries as well as full legal text.
 
Analogous to above-mentioned CC licenses are ODC-By (Open Data Commons Attribution Licence) and PDDL (Public Domain Dedication and Licence). Again, it isn’t recommended to use a ShareAlike licence. Open Data Commons licences are strictly spoken preferable, but not as widely used as CC licences.
 
Other licences
Datenlizenz Deutschland was created for administrative government data. While consistent with international open data standards and having licence text in both German and English, an international audience may not be familiar with these licences.
 
All mentioned licences allow open re-use of data, subject to certain conditions. Some use cases may require different licences, e.g. allowing commercial re-use subject to payment of a fee or restricting access to (personal) data. The Edmond repository only accepts open access data.
finalize.overview:
After research
Share your data for lasting (extra) impact
Data have potential value beyond their initial intent – verification of interpretations, new analysis methods, new insights based on comparison and/or combination with other data. They therefore need to be preserved and archived beyond the lifetime of a scientific project. Funding organizations generally require that data are kept for ten years – see e.g. Rules of Good Scientific Practice of the Max Planck Society and Kodex “Leitlinien zur Sicherung guter wissenschaftlicher Praxis” (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft).
 
If not done earlier, data should – as much as possible – be converted to open and sustainable formats at this stage.
 
Data sharing
 
You may wish to make your data freely available after conclusion of a scientific project. This could include data that did not answer your research question, but might prove useful in the future for other (unanticipated) research questions. It could also include "negative results".
 
For data supporting scientific publications, data sharing is often required by publishers. Yet in some cases, e.g. personal data or commercially sensitive data, data cannot be (freely) shared – “as open as possible, as closed as needed”. If work on data continues beyond the lifetime of a project, data can be deposited and put under embargo. Data licences clarify how data can be re-used, and should thus always be provided.
 
The preferred way of sharing data is deposition in a repository or data archive (see below). Sharing data solely via a project, departmental or personal homepage is unlikely to comply with funder and publisher expectations regarding long-term preservation, as these resources aren’t necessarily sustainable. Supplementary material attached to a journal article is a ‘traditional’ way of sharing data – but data may be (like the article itself) behind a paywall, and this option may offer limited flexibility about formats and may not be suitable for large datasets.
 
Data journals 
are a relatively recent option for describing and documenting data, with such outputs being peer-reviewed and receiving a status comparable to conventional scientific manuscripts. Scientific context will be provided without detailed interpretation of data. Data themselves are generally deposited in a repository and linked from the data paper. Some data journals also accept articles describing data services or best practices in data sharing.
 
List of data journals (HU Berlin)
finalize.repositories:
Data repositories
A home for your data
The number of data repositories keeps increasing, re3data.org currently lists more than 2000 repositories. This compilation can be browsed by subject, content type or country, and further searched by e.g. type of data access (open, restricted, embargoed, closed) or metadata standards (generic e.g. Dublin Core and/or discipline-specific).
 
Repositories are locations for depositing and sharing data, and thereby obviously also a source to find data for potential reuse. They ensure long-term availability of data, and generally provide persistent identifiers (mainly DOI) for data citation.
 
Repositories can be general (accepting a wide range of data from any scientist), institutional (also often content covering a wide range of scientific fields, but data upload contingent on institutional affiliation) or discipline-specific.
 
Discipline-specific repositories are recommended, as they provide more opportunities (but also obligations) to document data according to needs and standards of a scientific field. Data are also more likely to be discovered by other scientists working in the same or closely related fields. Various journals/publishers have lists of recommended repositories:
 
Scientific Data (Springer Nature) recommended data repositories
 
PLoS ONE (applying to all PLOS journals)
 
PeerJ Data and Materials Sharing

structure.intro:
Overview
Data management - do yourself and others a favor
Digital data are the foundation of all scientific research. The increasing amount and complexity of scientific data – in terms of data types, file formats, file sizes and number of files – poses challenges to keep data organized and documented and to make them available for verification of research and new analyses leading to new insights.
 
The DFG Kodex “Leitlinien zur Sicherung guter wissenschaftlicher Praxis”, applicable since August 2019, emphasizes the importance of documenting research (Leitlinie 12). It encourages scientists to make research data publicly available (Leitlinie 13) and to archive data for the long term (generally ten years, Leitlinie 17). In 2017, the EU Framework Programme Horizon 2020 extended their Open Research Data Pilot to cover all thematic areas, making open access to research data the default option.
 
Data management involves data organization and documentation, secure storage and in many cases open data sharing. The purpose of these pages is to provide data management guidance throughout the research process, introducing MPDL tools and services to help researchers of the Max Planck Society (and their collaboration partners).
 
Tooooools !!!
 
Why data management?
It is good scientific practice, ensuring that research can be verified and reproduced. Moreover, data can be re-used – on their own or combined with other data – including in ways not anticipated by initial data creators. This can also prevent duplication of research efforts.
 
 
It is increasingly required by funding agencies and publishers. Funding agencies want outputs of publicly funded research to reach a wide audience. Publishers insist that data underlying scientific papers are made available.
 
Last but not least, it is in your own interest, for two reasons:
  • You can get credit for sharing your data, it creates additional exposure for your research, may lead to new collaborations, ….. .
  • It enables you to keep track of your own data and facilitates working together in research teams. Without efforts to organize and document your data, are you sure to find and understand them five years from now? Will your collaborators understand your data? You may end up being the first re-user of your own data. It may be necessary to re-analyze raw data upon request from e.g. your supervisor or journal reviewers, or even after publication if your interpretations and conclusions are questioned/challenged. Data loss could happen for many reasons and at any inconvenient moment such as the final phase of a Ph.D. thesis.
 
Data management does not imply that all data have to be shared immediately. Data publication can be delayed until after publication of research findings; sensitive data might be shared with a limited audience and only under certain conditions, or not at all.
What are research data ?
There is no straightforward definition applicable to all scientific fields – the broadest one would be “anything needed to underpin scientific research“, i.e. to validate and reproduce research findings. While physical samples may also be considered “data”, we here focus on digital (or digitized) objects.
 
Partly dependent on scientific field and research questions, data can be quantitative or qualitative, come in various formats, and are generated with a range of methods (e.g. field observations, experiments, model output, interviews/polls). Raw data are the initial primary results, processed data are the product of subsequent steps, e.g. data cleaning, quality control, data aggregation, statistical analysis.
 
Tools used during such steps – code, scripts, software if not widely available – are also research data. Preserving, documenting and – to the extent possible – sharing your data processing workflow contributes to research reproducibility (by others or even by your future self) and is thus good scientific practice.
Metadata
“Data about data” are equally relevant for discovery and understanding of scientific datasets. Depending on characteristics of dataset and intended audience, various levels of detail may be adequate. Metadata can cover the following aspects:
  • bibliographic information (title, author, …)
  • contextual information (subject, geographical location, temporal coverage, keywords, …)
  • administrative aspects (date of creation, file type, access rights, …)
  • technical metadata (file properties and file sizes, …)
 
Metadata can be contained in the file itself, in a separate Readme file, or on a landing page for datasets – preferred option for using search tools.
  • Dublin Core is a widely used generic metadata standard.
 

For discipline-specific standards, see

  • Data Curation Centre List of Metadata Standards
  • Research Data Alliance’s Metadata Standards Directory
structure.website:
Structure of this website
The main content is presented in terms of "Before - During - After resarch", followed by a description of MPDL tools/services to help researchers. However, for data management purposes phases of the research process aren't necessarily distinct - some aspects should be considered at an early stage but require attention throughout a project.
 
Before research ("Start your project"): Early planning can save time at later stages of the research process, data management plans are increasingly required by research funders. Other subchapters are Legal-Ethical (how to deal with personal research data), file handling (file nomenclature, organization and versioning) and file formats (sustainable and preferably open ones are recommended).
During research ("Keep it running"): The main data management task during this phase is to store data safely as they are generated, with regular backups. Beyond and/or before storage, MPDL tools/services also support data acquisition and collaborative working during scientific projects.
After research ("Finalize it"): Data matter beyond the lifetime of a scientific research project, funding organizations generally require that data are kept for ten years. Publishers often require open sharing of data related to scientific publications. This section includes chapters on data repositories and licences recommended for scientific data.
MPDL Tools and Services help researchers for data acquisition (labfolder, LabCam), data storage and collaborative working (Keeper, «collective»), open data sharing (Edmond, DOI service) and long-term archival (Keeper, having a dual function). All services are briefly introduced, including how they can be contacted.

Privacy policy
Datenerhebung und Datenverarbeitung

Die MPDL legt großen Wert den Schutz und die Sicherheit personenbezogener Daten. Dabei richten wir uns nach den entsprechenden Vorgaben des Bundesdatenschutzgesetzes (BDSG) sowie der EU-Datenschutz-Grundverordnung (DSGV).

Auf dieser Seite erhalten Sie genaue Informationen dazu, welche Arten von Daten zu welchen Zwecken erfasst und verarbeitet werden.

Umfang der Datenverarbeitung

Wir erheben und verwenden personenbezogene Nutzerdaten grundsätzlich nur, soweit dies zur Bereitstellung einer funktionsfähigen Website sowie unserer Inhalte und Leistungen erforderlich ist. Die Erhebung und Verwendung personenbezogener Daten unserer Nutzer erfolgt regelmäßig nach Einwilligung der Nutzer. Eine Ausnahme gilt in solchen Fällen, in denen die Verarbeitung der Daten durch gesetzliche Vorschriften gestattet ist.

Rechtsgrundlage der Datenverarbeitung

Soweit wir für Verarbeitungsvorgänge personenbezogener Daten eine Einwilligung der betroffenen Person einholen, dient Art. 6 Abs. 1 lit. a EU-Datenschutzgrundverordnung (DSGVO) als Rechtsgrundlage.

Bei der Verarbeitung von personenbezogenen Daten, die zur Erfüllung eines Vertrages, dessen Vertragspartei die betroffene Person ist, erforderlich ist, dient Art. 6 Abs. 1 lit. b DSGVO als Rechtsgrundlage. Dies gilt auch für Verarbeitungsvorgänge, die zur Durchführung vorvertraglicher Maßnahmen erforderlich sind.

Ist die Verarbeitung zur Wahrung eines berechtigten Interesses der MPG oder eines Dritten erforderlich und überwiegen die Interessen, Grundrechte und Grundfreiheiten des Betroffenen das erstgenannte Interesse nicht, so dient Art. 6 Abs. 1 lit. f DSGVO als Rechtsgrundlage für die Verarbeitung.

Auskunft, Berichtigung, Löschung und Sperrung, Widerspruchsrecht

Sie sind gemäß § 34 BDSG (Art. 15 DSGVO) jederzeit berechtigt, gegenüber der MPDL um umfangreiche Auskunftserteilung zu den zu Ihrer Person gespeicherten Daten zu ersuchen.

Ebenso können Sie Gemäß § 35 BDSG jederzeit gegenüber der MPDL die Berichtigung (Art. 16 DSGVO), Löschung (Art. 17 DSGVO) und Sperrung (Art. 18 DSGVO) einzelner personenbezogener Daten verlangen.

Sie haben darüber hinaus das Recht, gemäß Art. 21 DSGVO Widerspruch gegen die Verarbeitung Ihrer personenbezogenen Daten einzulegen, soweit dafür Gründe vorliegen, die sich aus Ihrer besonderen Situation ergeben.

Sie können den Widerspruch entweder postalisch, per E-Mail oder per Fax an die MPDL übermitteln.

Sie haben das Recht, sich bei der zuständigen Aufsichtsbehörde zu beschweren (Art. 77 DSGVO). Dies ist für die MPG das Bayerische Landesamt für Datenschutzaufsicht, Postfach 606, 91511 Ansbach.

Protokolldateien (Logs)

Aus technischen Gründen speichern unsere Server bei Ihrem Zugriff auf Max Planck Digital Library personenbezogene Verbindungsdetails in ihren Protokolldateien, den sogenannten Logfiles.

Folgende Daten werden vorübergehend gespeichert:

  • Ihre IP-Adresse
  • Datum und Uhrzeit Ihres Zugriffs auf die Seite
  • Adresse der aufgerufenen Seite
  • Adresse der zuvor besuchten Webseite (Referrer)
  • Name und Version Ihres Browsers/Betriebssystems (sofern übertragen)

Die Erfassung der Daten zur Bereitstellung der Website und die Speicherung der Daten in Logfiles ist für den Betrieb der Webseite zwingend erforderlich. Diese Daten werden lediglich zur unmittelbaren Bereitstellung unserer Dienste, zur Störungsbeseitigung oder zur Abwehr eines Angriffs genutzt und nach kurzer Zeit automatisch gelöscht.

Rechtsgrundlage für die vorübergehende Speicherung der Daten und der Logfiles ist Art. 6 Abs. 1 f) DSGVO. Die Speicherung in Logfiles erfolgt, um die Funktionsfähigkeit der Website sicherzustellen. Zudem dienen uns die Daten zur Optimierung der Webseiten, zur Störungsbeseitigung und zur Sicherstellung der Sicherheit unserer informationstechnischen Systeme. In diesen Zwecken liegt auch unser berechtigtes Interesse an der Datenverarbeitung

Cookies

Um Ihnen die Nutzung unserer Webseite zu erleichtern, verwenden wir sog. "Session-Cookies". Dabei handelt es sich um kleine Textdateien, die nur für die Dauer Ihres Besuchs unserer Webseite auf Ihrer Festplatte hinterlegt und abhängig von der Einstellung Ihres Browser-Programms beim Beenden des Browsers wieder gelöscht werden. Diese Cookies rufen keine auf Ihrer Festplatte über Sie gespeicherten Informationen ab und beeinträchtigen nicht Ihren PC oder ihre Dateien.

Die meisten Browser sind so eingestellt, dass sie Cookies automatisch akzeptieren. Sie können das Speichern von Cookies jedoch deaktivieren oder ihren Browser so einstellen, dass er Sie auf die Sendung von Cookies hinweist.

Bitte beachten Sie, dass einzelne Funktionen unserer Website beeinträchtigt werden könnten, wenn Sie die Verwendung von Cookies deaktiviert haben.

Webanalyse

Wir setzen zur statistischen Datenerfassung des Nutzungsverhaltens das Webanalytik-Programm Matomo (ehemals Piwik) ein, das mit Cookies und JavaScript verschiedene Informationen auf Ihrem Computer sammelt und automatisiert an uns überträgt. Bei jedem Aufruf unserer Webseiten erfasst unser System folgende Daten und Informationen vom Computersystem des aufrufenden Rechners:

  • IP-Adresse, durch Verkürzen anonymisiert
  • Zwei Cookies zur Unterscheidung verschiedener Besucher (pk_id und pk_sess)
  • Zuvor besuchte URL (Referrer), sofern vom Browser übermittelt
  • Name und Version des Betriebssystems
  • Name, Version und Spracheinstellung des Browsers

Zusätzlich, sofern JavaScript aktiviert ist:

  • Besuchte URLs auf dieser Webseite
  • Zeitpunkte der Seitenaufrufe
  • Art der HTML-Anfragen
  • Bildschirmauflösung und Farbtiefe
  • Vom Browser unterstützte Techniken und Formate (z. B. Cookies, Java, Flash, PDF, WindowsMedia, QuickTime, Realplayer, Director, SilverLight, Google Gears)

Die Speicherung und Auswertung der Daten erfolgt ausschließlich auf einem zentralen Server, der von der MPG betrieben wird. Neben der zentralen Webseite www.mpg.de wird es auch von den meisten Max-Planck-Instituten und vielen der MPG zugeordneten Projekt-Webseiten genutzt.

Rechtsgrundlage für die Verarbeitung der personenbezogenen Daten der Nutzer ist Art. 6 Abs. 1 lit. f DSGVO. Die Verarbeitung der personenbezogenen Daten der Nutzer ermöglicht uns eine Analyse des Nutzungsverhaltens unserer Nutzer. Wir sind durch die Auswertung der gewonnenen Daten in der Lage, Informationen über die Nutzung der einzelnen Komponenten unserer Webseiten zusammenzustellen. Dies hilft uns dabei unsere Webseiten und deren Nutzerfreundlichkeit stetig zu verbessern. In diesen Zwecken liegt auch unser berechtigtes Interesse in der Verarbeitung der Daten nach Art. 6 Abs. 1 lit. f DSGVO. Durch die Anonymisierung der IP-Adresse wird dem Interesse der Nutzer an deren Schutz personenbezogener Daten hinreichend Rechnung getragen.

Die Daten werden nach der Bildung der abschließenden Jahressummen für die Zugriffsstatistik gelöscht.

Selbstverständlich haben Sie die Möglichkeit der Datenerhebung zu widersprechen. Sie haben folgende unabhängige Möglichkeiten einer Datenerfassung durch den zentralen Server zu widersprechen:

  1. Aktivieren Sie in Ihrem Browser die Einstellung Do-Not-Track bzw. Nicht folgen. Solange diese Einstellung aktiv ist, wird unser zentraler Matomo-Server keinerlei Daten von Ihnen speichern. Wichtig: Die Do-Not-Track-Anweisung gilt in der Regel nur für das eine Gerät und den einen Browser, in dem Sie die Einstellung aktivieren. Sollten Sie mehrere Geräte/Browser nutzen, dann müssen Sie Do-Not-Tracküberall separat aktivieren.
  2. Nutzen Sie unsere Opt-Out-Funktion: In der Erklärung zur Datenerhebung.

Die Speicherung und Auswertung erfolgt grundsätzlich anonymisiert. Session-Cookies werden spätestens mit dem Schließen Ihres Browsers gelöscht.

Personenbezogene Nutzerprofile werden nicht erstellt.

Externe Dienste

Auch die Einbindung von externen Diensten, wie beispielsweise Google Maps oder Open Street Map für Anfahrtsbeschreibungen, Youtube bzw. Amazon Cloud für Videos erfolgen stets überlegt und mit dem Ziel, den Besuch auf unseren Webseiten für Sie so angenehm wie möglich zu gestalten.

Wir müssen Sie aber darauf hinweisen, dass auf diesem Weg Ihre IP-Adresse und möglicherweise weitere personenbezogenen Daten an den jeweiligen Dienstleister (Google, Amazon, etc.) übertragen und eventuell gespeichert und ausgewertet werden.

Datenübermittlung

Ihre personenbezogenen Daten werden nur in den gesetzlich erforderlichen Fällen bzw. zur Strafverfolgung aufgrund von Angriffen auf unsere Netzinfrastruktur an staatliche Einrichtungen und Behörden übermittelt. Eine Weitergabe zu anderen Zwecken an Dritte findet nicht statt.

Änderungen der Datenschutzbestimmungen

Diese Datenschutzerklärung kann ggf. im Laufe der Zeit angepasst werden, weil sich die rechtlichen Rahmenbedingungen geändert haben oder weil neue Funktionalitäten oder Services dies erfordern.

Mit der Nutzung der Webseite erklären Sie sich mit den geänderten Bedingungen dieser Richtlinien zum Schutz persönlicher Daten einverstanden.

Fragen an die Datenschutzbeauftragte

Für Fragen zum Thema Datenschutz steht Ihnen die Datenschutzbeauftragte der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft per E-Mail an datenschutz[at]mpg.de oder telefonisch unter +49 89 2108-1554 zur Verfügung.
